awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Expanding the Frontiers of Lattice-Based Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Research and development into quantum computers raises many new challenges for security and privacy. For instance, large-scale quantum computers would compromise much of the cryptography used to secure the Internet today. This project's novelty is in developing new and systematic approaches for constructing advanced cryptographic primitives that remain robust even in the presence of sophisticated quantum adversaries. The project's impacts are in enabling and realizing new and secure cryptographic primitives and mechanisms to safeguard our critical digital infrastructure from the potential threat posed by quantum computers.

The focus of this project is on lattice-based cryptography, a popular class of mathematical assumptions believed to be resistant against quantum attacks. This project investigates new constructions of core cryptographic primitives, such as zero-knowledge proof systems, pseudorandom functions, and software watermarking from standard lattice-based assumptions. These primitives are important building blocks in systems for outsourcing computations in the cloud as well as for protecting against unauthorized distribution of software. In addition, the investigator develops new cryptography courses and advises undergraduate and graduate students to prepare them with the expertise necessary for designing the next generation of secure computing systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research and development in quantum computing raises new challenges for security and cryptography. Large-scale quantum computers would compromise many of the cryptographic protocols that secure our cloud computing infrastructure. The focus of this project was lattice-based cryptography, one of the most popular classes of mathematical assumptions currently believed to be resistant against quantum attacks. The primary goal of this project was to expand the capabilities of lattice-based cryptography. This project tackled this from two main angles:

  • Theoretical feasibility: One of the thrusts of this project focused on constructing new cryptographic primitives with advanced capabilities from lattice-based assumptions. These included constructions for software protection, succinct arguments, functional commitments, and more.
  • Concrete efficiency: Another appealing feature of lattice-based cryptography is their efficiency. Compared to traditional number-theoretic assumptions like the hardness of discrete log or factoring, lattice-based constructions are often faster. Thus, they are an appealing tool for building privacy-preserving systems. This project also explored the possibility of using lattices to construct highly efficient privacy-preserving systems.

This project made scientific advancements along both of these key directions. In terms of intellectual merits, the PI and his collaborators published a number of works that advanced the state-of-the-art in lattice-based cryptography. We summarize some of the main results below:

  • We introduced the notion of a traceable pseudorandom function (PRF) and showed how to construct it from lattice-based assumptions. A traceable PRF is a primitive that allows a user to embed identifying information (e.g., a name or a serial number) into a cryptographic key. If the key is ever stolen or compromised, it is possible to identify the legitimate owner of the key. We additionally showed that earlier notions of software watermarking introduced for this problem did not provide sufficiently-strong security guarantees for applications.
  • We introduced the first functional commitment for general circuits from lattice-based assumptions. Functional commitments are a useful tool for ensuring the integrity of computations (e.g., a client outsources a computation to a cloud server and would like a short guarantee that the computation was performed correctly).
  • We gave the first multi-authority attribute-based encryption scheme from standard lattice assumptions in the plain model. This is an encryption scheme that supports fine-grained access control to encrypted data.
  • We used lattices to construct a concretely-efficient (designated-verifier) lattice-based succinct non-interactive argument (SNARG). Similar to functional commitments, succinct arguments are a useful building block for establishing integrity for computations, and are a key building block for authentication schemes, verifiable computation, and privacy-preserving cryptocurrencies. Our lattice-based arguments are both plausibly post-quantum secure and substantially faster to verify compared to previous constructions based on group-based assumptions.
  • We introduced a very efficient private information retrieval (PIR) scheme based on lattices. A PIR scheme allows a client to retrieve a record from a database without revealing which record was requested. To showcase the practicality of the protocol, we built a demo that allows a user to privately fetch a Wikipedia article (from a database containing roughly 30% of the articles from English Wikipedia) with a modest cost (just 4s of latency). The demo is available here: https://spiralwiki.com/

The broader impacts of the project are summarized below:

  • Funding from this award has supported the research of several PhD students at both the University of Virginia and at UT Austin.
  • The PI developed a new course on lattice-based cryptography at UT Austin (Spring 2021). Around 20 students enrolled in the course, and all of the course material are publicly available on the PI's website.
  • In collaboration with faculty at Texas A&M, UT Dallas, and the University of North Texas, the PI has started up a semi-annual Texas Crypto Day event. This is a one-way workshop where students and faculty across Texas come together to present the latest research in cryptography. The PI recently hosted the second iteration of the event at UT Austin in April 2023.
